testInfo.name: Gesamtfragenkatalog zum Test „Leben in Deutschland“ und zum „Einbürgerungstest“

questions.germanQuestion: Welche der folgenden Auflistungen enthält nur Bundesländer, die zum Gebiet der früheren DDR gehörten?
questions.englishQuestion: Which of the following lists contains only federal states that were part of the former GDR?

options.englishOption: Lower Saxony, North Rhine-Westphalia, Hesse, Schleswig-Holstein, Brandenburg
Saxony, Thuringia, Hesse, Lower Saxony, Brandenburg

questions.notes: The correct list includes Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Brandenburg, Saxony, Saxony-Anhalt, and Thuringia, which were all part of East Germany (GDR).
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on identifying the federal states that were part of the former East Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about the federal states of Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Zu wem gehörte die DDR im 'Kalten Krieg'?
questions.englishQuestion: Which alliance did the GDR belong to during the 'Cold War'?
questions.notes: During the Cold War, the GDR was aligned with the Warsaw Pact, which was the military alliance of communist states led by the Soviet Union.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the Warsaw Pact as the key alliance for the GDR during the Cold War.

resources.description: Learn more about the Warsaw Pact.

questions.germanQuestion: Wie hieß das Wirtschaftssystem der DDR?
questions.englishQuestion: What was the economic system of the GDR called?
questions.notes: The GDR had a centrally planned economy, where the state controlled production, distribution, and prices.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on 'Planwirtschaft' as the term for the centrally planned economy in the GDR.

resources.description: Learn more about the economic system of East Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wie wurden die Bundesrepublik Deutschland und die DDR zu einem Staat?
questions.englishQuestion: How did the Federal Republic of Germany and the GDR become one state?

options.germanOption: Die Bundesrepublik hat die DDR besetzt.
options.englishOption: The Federal Republic occupied the GDR.

options.germanOption: Die heutigen fünf östlichen Bundesländer sind der Bundesrepublik Deutschland beigetreten.
options.englishOption: The current five eastern federal states joined the Federal Republic of Germany.

options.germanOption: Die westlichen Bundesländer sind der DDR beigetreten.
options.englishOption: The western federal states joined the GDR.

options.germanOption: Die DDR hat die Bundesrepublik Deutschland besetzt.
options.englishOption: The GDR occupied the Federal Republic of Germany.

questions.notes: The reunification of Germany occurred when the five new eastern federal states (former GDR) joined the Federal Republic of Germany in 1990.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the accession of the eastern federal states as the key step in German reunification.

resources.description: Learn more about German reunification.

questions.germanQuestion: Mit dem Beitritt der DDR zur Bundesrepublik Deutschland gehören die neuen Bundesländer nun auch …
questions.englishQuestion: With the accession of the GDR to the Federal Republic of Germany, the new federal states are now also part of …
questions.notes: After reunification, the new federal states that joined Germany also became part of the European Union.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the fact that reunification also meant integration into European structures like the EU.

resources.description: Learn more about the European Union and German reunification.

questions.germanQuestion: Woran erinnern die sogenannten 'Stolpersteine' in Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: What do the so-called 'Stolpersteine' (stumbling stones) in Germany commemorate?

options.germanOption: an berühmte deutsche Politikerinnen und Politiker

questions.notes: The Stolpersteine (stumbling stones) are small brass plaques embedded in the pavement to commemorate individuals who were persecuted and killed by the Nazis.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the Stolpersteine as a grassroots project that memorializes victims of the Holocaust.

resources.description: Learn more about the Stolpersteine project.

questions.germanQuestion: In welchem Militärbündnis war die DDR Mitglied?
questions.englishQuestion: In which military alliance was the GDR a member?

options.englishOption: in the Confederation of the Rhine

questions.notes: The GDR (East Germany) was a member of the Warsaw Pact, the military alliance of socialist states led by the Soviet Union during the Cold War.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that the Warsaw Pact was the Eastern Bloc's counterpart to NATO during the Cold War.

resources.description: Learn more about the Warsaw Pact.

questions.germanQuestion: Was war die 'Stasi'?
questions.englishQuestion: What was the 'Stasi'?

options.englishOption: the secret service in the 'Third Reich'
the secret service of the GDR

options.germanOption: ein deutscher Sportverein während des Zweiten Weltkrieges
options.englishOption: a German sports club during World War II

questions.notes: The Stasi was the state security service of the GDR (East Germany), responsible for surveillance and intelligence gathering.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember 'Stasi' as the secret police organization of East Germany, known for its extensive surveillance of citizens.

resources.description: Learn more about the Stasi.

questions.germanQuestion: Welches war das Wappen der Deutschen Demokratischen Republik?
questions.englishQuestion: Which was the coat of arms of the German Democratic Republic?
questions.notes: The coat of arms of the GDR featured a hammer and compass surrounded by a wreath of wheat, symbolizing the unity of workers, peasants, and intelligentsia.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the unique symbolism in the GDR's coat of arms, which reflected its socialist ideology.

resources.description: Learn more about the coat of arms of East Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Was ereignete sich am 17. Juni 1953 in der DDR?
questions.englishQuestion: What happened on June 17, 1953, in the GDR?

options.germanOption: der feierliche Beitritt zum Warschauer Pakt
options.englishOption: the ceremonial accession to the Warsaw Pact
nationwide strikes and a popular uprising
the first visit of Fidel Castro

questions.notes: On June 17, 1953, a popular uprising and nationwide strikes broke out in the GDR, which were violently suppressed by the government with Soviet support.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on June 17, 1953, as a significant date of resistance against the East German government.

resources.description: Learn more about the 1953 uprising in East Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Welcher Politiker steht für die 'Ostverträge'?
questions.englishQuestion: Which politician is associated with the 'Eastern Treaties'?
questions.notes: Willy Brandt is known for his role in the 'Ostverträge,' a series of treaties that aimed to normalize relations between West Germany and Eastern Europe during the Cold War.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember Willy Brandt's 'Ostpolitik' as the key policy that opened relations with Eastern European countries.

resources.description: Learn more about the Eastern Treaties and Willy Brandt's Ostpolitik.

questions.germanQuestion: Wie heißt Deutschland mit vollem Namen?
questions.englishQuestion: What is the full name of Germany?
questions.notes: Germany's full official name is 'Bundesrepublik Deutschland' (Federal Republic of Germany).
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the official designation 'Bundesrepublik Deutschland,' which reflects Germany's structure as a federal republic.

resources.description: Learn more about the official name of Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wie viele Einwohner hat Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: How many inhabitants does Germany have?
questions.notes: As of recent estimates, Germany has approximately 84 million inhabitants, making it the most populous country in the European Union.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on 84 million as the current population of Germany, reflecting its significant size in Europe.

resources.description: Learn more about Germany's population.

questions.germanQuestion: Welche Farben hat die deutsche Flagge?
questions.englishQuestion: What are the colors of the German flag?
questions.notes: The colors of the German flag are black, red, and gold, which have historical significance dating back to the 19th century.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the black-red-gold color combination, which is a key symbol of German national identity.

resources.description: Learn more about the German flag and its history.

questions.germanQuestion: Wer wird als 'Kanzler der Deutschen Einheit' bezeichnet?
questions.englishQuestion: Who is referred to as the 'Chancellor of German Unity'?
questions.notes: Helmut Kohl is known as the 'Chancellor of German Unity' for his role in the reunification of Germany in 1990.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on Helmut Kohl's key role in the reunification process, which earned him this title.

resources.description: Learn more about Helmut Kohl and German reunification.

questions.germanQuestion: Welches Symbol ist im Plenarsaal des Deutschen Bundestages zu sehen?
questions.englishQuestion: Which symbol can be seen in the plenary hall of the German Bundestag?

options.englishOption: the flag of the city of Berlin

questions.notes: The Federal Eagle, known as the 'Bundesadler,' is the symbol of the Federal Republic of Germany and is prominently displayed in the plenary hall of the Bundestag.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the Federal Eagle as the national emblem of Germany and a key symbol of the Bundestag.

resources.description: Learn more about the German Bundestag and its symbols.

questions.germanQuestion: In welchem Zeitraum gab es die Deutsche Demokratische Republik (DDR)?
questions.englishQuestion: During which period did the German Democratic Republic (GDR) exist?
questions.notes: The German Democratic Republic (GDR) existed from 1949 until 1990, when it was reunified with the Federal Republic of Germany.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember 1949 to 1990 as the period during which East Germany (GDR) existed.

resources.description: Learn more about the history of East Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wie viele Bundesländer kamen bei der Wiedervereinigung 1990 zur Bundesrepublik Deutschland hinzu?
questions.englishQuestion: How many federal states were added to the Federal Republic of Germany during reunification in 1990?
questions.notes: During the reunification of Germany in 1990, five new federal states (Brandenburg, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Saxony, Saxony-Anhalt, and Thuringia) were added to the Federal Republic of Germany.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the addition of five new federal states during German reunification.

resources.description: Learn more about German reunification and its impact on the federal states.

questions.germanQuestion: Die Bundesrepublik Deutschland hat die Grenzen von heute seit …
questions.englishQuestion: The Federal Republic of Germany has had its current borders since …
questions.notes: Germany's current borders were established in 1990 following the reunification of East and West Germany.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that Germany's current borders were established with reunification in 1990.

resources.description: Learn more about the history of Germany's borders.

questions.germanQuestion: Der 27. Januar ist in Deutschland ein offizieller Gedenktag. Woran erinnert dieser Tag?
questions.englishQuestion: January 27 is an official day of remembrance in Germany. What does this day commemorate?

options.germanOption: an das Ende des Zweiten Weltkrieges
options.englishOption: the end of World War II
the adoption of the Basic Law (Grundgesetz)

options.germanOption: an die Opfer des Nationalsozialismus (Tag der Befreiung des Vernichtungslagers Auschwitz)
options.englishOption: the victims of National Socialism (Day of the Liberation of Auschwitz concentration camp)

questions.notes: January 27 is an official day of remembrance in Germany, dedicated to the victims of National Socialism. It marks the anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz concentration camp in 1945.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on January 27 as the day Germany commemorates the victims of the Holocaust.

resources.description: Learn more about Holocaust Remembrance Day in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Deutschland ist Mitglied des Schengener Abkommens. Was bedeutet das?
questions.englishQuestion: Germany is a member of the Schengen Agreement. What does that mean?

options.germanOption: Deutsche können in viele Länder Europas ohne Passkontrolle reisen.
options.englishOption: Germans can travel to many European countries without passport control.

options.germanOption: Alle Menschen können ohne Personenkontrolle in Deutschland einreisen.
options.englishOption: All people can enter Germany without identity checks.

options.germanOption: Deutsche können ohne Passkontrolle in jedes Land reisen.
options.englishOption: Germans can travel to any country without passport control.

options.germanOption: Deutsche können in jedem Land mit dem Euro bezahlen.
options.englishOption: Germans can pay with the euro in every country.

questions.notes: The Schengen Agreement allows for passport-free travel between many European countries, facilitating freedom of movement for Germans and others.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the Schengen Agreement as the key to understanding free movement within many European countries.

resources.description: Learn more about the Schengen Agreement.

questions.germanQuestion: Welches Land ist ein Nachbarland von Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: Which country is a neighbor of Germany?
questions.notes: Switzerland shares a border with Germany to the south, making it one of Germany's nine neighboring countries.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on Switzerland as one of Germany's neighbors, along with eight other countries.

resources.description: Learn more about Germany's neighboring countries.

questions.germanQuestion: Welches Land ist ein Nachbarland von Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: Which country is a neighbor of Germany?
questions.notes: Poland is one of Germany's eastern neighbors, sharing a significant border.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on Poland as one of the key neighboring countries to the east of Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about Germany's neighboring countries.

questions.germanQuestion: Was bedeutet die Abkürzung EU?
questions.englishQuestion: What does the abbreviation EU stand for?
questions.notes: The EU stands for the European Union, a political and economic union of member states located primarily in Europe.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on 'Europäische Union' as the full name for the abbreviation 'EU'.

resources.description: Learn more about the European Union.

questions.germanQuestion: In welchem anderen Land gibt es eine große deutschsprachige Bevölkerung?
questions.englishQuestion: In which other country is there a large German-speaking population?
questions.notes: Austria is a neighboring country of Germany where German is the official language and the primary spoken language.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on Austria as a key German-speaking country outside of Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about German-speaking countries.

questions.germanQuestion: Welche ist die Flagge der Europäischen Union?
questions.englishQuestion: Which is the flag of the European Union?
questions.notes: The flag of the European Union is blue with a circle of 12 gold stars.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the circle of 12 stars on a blue background, representing unity in Europe.

resources.description: Learn more about the flag of the European Union.

questions.germanQuestion: Welches Land ist ein Nachbarland von Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: Which country is a neighbor of Germany?
questions.notes: Denmark shares a northern border with Germany.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on Denmark as Germany's northern neighbor.

resources.description: Learn more about Germany's neighboring countries.

questions.germanQuestion: Wie wird der Beitritt der DDR zur Bundesrepublik Deutschland im Jahr 1990 allgemein genannt?
questions.englishQuestion: How is the accession of the GDR to the Federal Republic of Germany in 1990 generally called?
questions.notes: The process of the GDR joining the Federal Republic of Germany in 1990 is commonly referred to as the 'German Reunification.'
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on 'Deutsche Wiedervereinigung' as the term for the reunification of East and West Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about German reunification.

questions.germanQuestion: Welches Land ist ein Nachbarland von Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: Which country is a neighbor of Germany?
questions.notes: Luxembourg shares a western border with Germany.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on Luxembourg as one of Germany's neighbors to the west.

resources.description: Learn more about Germany's neighboring countries.

questions.germanQuestion: Das Europäische Parlament wird regelmäßig gewählt, nämlich alle …
questions.englishQuestion: The European Parliament is elected regularly, namely every …
questions.notes: The European Parliament is elected every five years by citizens of EU member states.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the five-year election cycle for the European Parliament.

resources.description: Learn more about the European Parliament.

questions.germanQuestion: Was bedeutet der Begriff 'europäische Integration'?
questions.englishQuestion: What does the term 'European integration' mean?

options.germanOption: Damit sind amerikanische Einwanderinnen und Einwanderer in Europa gemeint.
options.englishOption: It refers to American immigrants in Europe.

options.germanOption: Der Begriff meint den Einwanderungsstopp nach Europa.
options.englishOption: The term refers to a stop to immigration into Europe.

options.germanOption: Damit sind europäische Auswanderinnen und Auswanderer in den USA gemeint.
options.englishOption: It refers to European emigrants in the USA.

options.germanOption: Der Begriff meint den Zusammenschluss europäischer Staaten zur EU.
options.englishOption: The term refers to the integration of European states into the EU.

questions.notes: European integration refers to the political, economic, and legal consolidation of European states, especially through the European Union.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'europäische Integration' is associated with the formation of the EU.

resources.description: Learn more about European integration and the EU.

questions.germanQuestion: Wer wird bei der Europawahl gewählt?
questions.englishQuestion: Who is elected in the European Parliament election?

options.germanOption: die Länder, die in die EU eintreten dürfen
options.englishOption: the countries allowed to join the EU
the Members of the European Parliament

questions.notes: In the European Parliament election, citizens of EU member states elect representatives to the European Parliament.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the election of Members of the European Parliament as the main outcome of the European elections.

resources.description: Learn more about the European Parliament election.

questions.germanQuestion: Welches Land ist ein Nachbarland von Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: Which country is a neighbor of Germany?
questions.notes: The Czech Republic shares a border with Germany to the east.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the Czech Republic as one of Germany's eastern neighbors.

resources.description: Learn more about Germany's neighboring countries.

questions.germanQuestion: Wo ist der Sitz des Europäischen Parlaments?
questions.englishQuestion: Where is the seat of the European Parliament?
questions.notes: The European Parliament's official seat is in Strasbourg, France.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on Strasbourg as the official location of the European Parliament.

resources.description: Learn more about the European Parliament's seat.

questions.germanQuestion: Der damalige französische Staatspräsident François Mitterrand und der damalige deutsche Bundeskanzler Helmut Kohl gedenken in Verdun gemeinsam der Toten beider Weltkriege. Welches Ziel der Europäischen Union wird bei diesem Treffen deutlich?
questions.englishQuestion: The then French President François Mitterrand and the then German Chancellor Helmut Kohl jointly commemorate the dead of both world wars in Verdun. Which goal of the European Union is highlighted by this meeting?

options.germanOption: Reisefreiheit in alle Länder der EU
options.englishOption: Freedom of travel in all EU countries

options.germanOption: Frieden und Sicherheit in den Ländern der EU
options.englishOption: Peace and security in the countries of the EU

options.germanOption: einheitliche Feiertage in den Ländern der EU
options.englishOption: Unified holidays in the countries of the EU

questions.notes: The meeting between Mitterrand and Kohl in Verdun symbolizes the commitment to peace and security within the European Union, one of its core objectives.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the EU's goal of promoting peace and security among its member states, as exemplified by this historic event.

resources.description: Learn more about the European Union's mission for peace and security.

questions.germanQuestion: Wie viele Mitgliedstaaten hat die EU heute?
questions.englishQuestion: How many member states does the EU have today?
questions.notes: As of today, the European Union has 27 member states.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the number 27 as the current number of EU member states.

resources.description: Learn more about the European Union and its member states.

questions.germanQuestion: 2007 wurde das 50-jährige Jubiläum der 'Römischen Verträge' gefeiert. Was war der Inhalt der Verträge?
questions.englishQuestion: In 2007, the 50th anniversary of the 'Treaties of Rome' was celebrated. What was the content of the treaties?

options.englishOption: Creation of the European Economic Community (EEC)
Establishment of the Oder-Neisse line as the eastern border

questions.notes: The Treaties of Rome, signed in 1957, established the European Economic Community (EEC) and are considered a cornerstone of European integration.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the Treaties of Rome as the foundation for the EEC and modern European integration.

resources.description: Learn more about the Treaties of Rome.

questions.germanQuestion: An welchen Orten arbeitet das Europäische Parlament?
questions.englishQuestion: In which locations does the European Parliament work?
questions.notes: The European Parliament operates in three locations: Strasbourg (official seat), Luxembourg (administrative offices), and Brussels (committee meetings and plenary sessions).
questions.learningTechniques: Remember the three key locations for the European Parliament's operations: Strasbourg, Luxembourg, and Brussels.

resources.description: Learn more about the locations of the European Parliament.

questions.germanQuestion: Durch welche Verträge schloss sich die Bundesrepublik Deutschland mit anderen Staaten zur Europäischen Wirtschaftsgemeinschaft zusammen?
questions.englishQuestion: Through which treaties did the Federal Republic of Germany join with other states to form the European Economic Community?
questions.notes: The Treaties of Rome, signed in 1957, established the European Economic Community (EEC), including the Federal Republic of Germany.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the Treaties of Rome as the foundation of the European Economic Community.

resources.description: Learn more about the Treaties of Rome.

questions.germanQuestion: Seit wann bezahlt man in Deutschland mit dem Euro in bar?
questions.englishQuestion: Since when has cash payment been made with the Euro in Germany?
questions.notes: The Euro was introduced as cash currency in Germany on January 1, 2002.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on 2002 as the year when the Euro became the official cash currency in Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about the introduction of the Euro.

questions.germanQuestion: Frau Seger bekommt ein Kind. Was muss sie tun, um Elterngeld zu erhalten?
questions.englishQuestion: Ms. Seger is having a child. What must she do to receive parental allowance?

options.germanOption: Sie muss an ihre Krankenkasse schreiben.
options.englishOption: She must write to her health insurance company.

options.germanOption: Sie muss einen Antrag bei der Elterngeldstelle stellen.
options.englishOption: She must apply to the parental allowance office.

options.germanOption: Sie muss nichts tun, denn sie bekommt automatisch Elterngeld.
options.englishOption: She doesn't have to do anything, she automatically receives parental allowance.

options.germanOption: Sie muss das Arbeitsamt um Erlaubnis bitten.
options.englishOption: She must ask the employment office for permission.

questions.notes: To receive parental allowance in Germany, an application must be submitted to the relevant office.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that parental allowance requires an application, it is not automatic.

resources.description: Learn more about parental allowance in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wer entscheidet, ob ein Kind in Deutschland in den Kindergarten geht?
questions.englishQuestion: Who decides whether a child goes to kindergarten in Germany?
questions.notes: In Germany, it is the parents or legal guardians who decide whether a child attends kindergarten.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that kindergarten attendance in Germany is not mandatory and is a decision made by parents.

resources.description: Learn more about the kindergarten system in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Maik und Sybille wollen mit Freunden an ihrem deutschen Wohnort eine Demonstration auf der Straße abhalten. Was müssen sie vorher tun?
questions.englishQuestion: Maik and Sybille want to hold a street demonstration with friends in their German hometown. What must they do beforehand?

options.germanOption: Sie müssen nichts tun. Man darf in Deutschland jederzeit überall demonstrieren.
options.englishOption: They don't have to do anything. You can demonstrate anywhere in Germany at any time.

options.germanOption: Sie können gar nichts tun, denn Demonstrationen sind in Deutschland grundsätzlich verboten.
options.englishOption: They can't do anything because demonstrations are fundamentally forbidden in Germany.

options.germanOption: Maik und Sybille müssen einen neuen Verein gründen, weil nur Vereine demonstrieren dürfen.
options.englishOption: Maik and Sybille must form a new association because only associations are allowed to demonstrate.

questions.notes: In Germany, demonstrations must be registered with the authorities, but they are allowed as part of the right to assembly.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the requirement of registering demonstrations as part of Germany's regulated freedom of assembly.

resources.description: Learn more about the right to demonstrate in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Welchen Schulabschluss braucht man normalerweise, um an einer Universität in Deutschland ein Studium zu beginnen?
questions.englishQuestion: Which school diploma is usually required to begin studies at a university in Germany?
questions.notes: The 'Abitur' is the qualification obtained at the end of secondary education in Germany, required for university admission.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'Abitur' is the standard university entrance qualification in Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about the Abitur and university admission in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wer darf in Deutschland nicht als Paar zusammenleben?
questions.englishQuestion: Who is not allowed to live together as a couple in Germany?

options.englishOption: Hans (20 years old) and Marie (19 years old)
Tom (20 years old) and Klaus (45 years old)
Sofie (35 years old) and Lisa (40 years old)
Anne (13 years old) and Tim (25 years old)

questions.notes: In Germany, it is illegal for minors (under 14) to live as a couple with adults.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the age of consent laws in Germany, which prevent minors from engaging in relationships with significantly older adults.

resources.description: Learn more about age of consent and legal relationships in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Ab welchem Alter ist man in Deutschland volljährig?
questions.englishQuestion: At what age does one reach legal adulthood in Germany?
questions.notes: In Germany, a person reaches legal adulthood at the age of 18.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 18 is the age of legal adulthood in most European countries, including Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about the age of legal adulthood in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Eine Frau ist schwanger. Sie ist kurz vor und nach der Geburt ihres Kindes vom Gesetz besonders beschützt. Wie heißt dieser Schutz?
questions.englishQuestion: A woman is pregnant. She is legally protected shortly before and after the birth of her child. What is this protection called?
questions.notes: The 'Mutterschutz' law in Germany provides legal protection for women shortly before and after childbirth, ensuring job security and health protection.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that 'Mutterschutz' ensures maternity protection rights for pregnant women and new mothers.

resources.description: Learn more about maternity protection laws in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Die Erziehung der Kinder ist in Deutschland ist vor allem Aufgabe …
questions.englishQuestion: The upbringing of children in Germany is primarily the responsibility of …
questions.notes: In Germany, the primary responsibility for raising children lies with the parents, while the state and schools provide support.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the role of parents as the primary caregivers and educators of their children in Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about the role of parents in child upbringing in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wer ist in Deutschland hauptsächlich verantwortlich für die Kindererziehung?
questions.englishQuestion: Who is primarily responsible for child upbringing in Germany?
questions.notes: Parents hold the primary responsibility for the upbringing of their children in Germany, as outlined in the Basic Law.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the legal framework in Germany that emphasizes parental responsibility for children.

resources.description: Learn more about child upbringing laws in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: In Deutschland hat man die besten Chancen auf einen gut bezahlten Arbeitsplatz, wenn man …
questions.englishQuestion: In Germany, one has the best chances of a well-paid job if they …

options.englishOption: are a member of a political party.

questions.notes: In Germany, education and qualifications are highly valued, which significantly increases job opportunities.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the importance of education and vocational training for employment opportunities in Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about education and job opportunities in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wenn man in Deutschland ein Kind schlägt, …
questions.englishQuestion: If you hit a child in Germany, …

options.germanOption: geht das nur die Familie etwas an.
kann man dafür nicht bestraft werden.
options.englishOption: you cannot be punished for it.
you can be punished for it.

questions.notes: Hitting children is illegal in Germany, and it is punishable by law as part of child protection.
questions.learningTechniques: Focus on the legal protection of children in Germany, which prohibits corporal punishment.

resources.description: Learn more about child protection laws in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: In Deutschland …
questions.englishQuestion: In Germany, …

options.germanOption: darf man zur gleichen Zeit nur mit einer Partnerin/einem Partner verheiratet sein.
options.englishOption: you are only allowed to be married to one partner at the same time.

options.germanOption: kann man mehrere Ehepartnerinnen/Ehepartner gleichzeitig haben.
options.englishOption: you can have multiple spouses at the same time.

options.germanOption: darf man nicht wieder heiraten, wenn man einmal verheiratet war.
options.englishOption: you cannot remarry if you have been married before.

options.germanOption: darf eine Frau nicht wieder heiraten, wenn ihr Mann gestorben ist.
options.englishOption: a woman cannot remarry if her husband has died.

questions.notes: Germany follows the principle of monogamy, where an individual can only be married to one partner at a time.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that monogamy is legally enforced in Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about marriage laws in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Wo müssen Sie sich anmelden, wenn Sie in Deutschland umziehen?

resources.description: Overview of the influence of Christianity on European culture.

questions.germanQuestion: In Deutschland nennt man die letzten vier Wochen vor Weihnachten …
questions.englishQuestion: In Germany, the last four weeks before Christmas are called …
questions.notes: The Advent season in Germany marks the four weeks leading up to Christmas, often associated with traditions like Advent calendars and wreaths.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that Advent is the preparation period before Christmas, with traditions observed across Germany.

resources.description: Learn more about Advent traditions in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Aus welchem Land sind die meisten Migrantinnen und Migranten nach Deutschland gekommen?
questions.englishQuestion: From which country have most migrants come to Germany?
questions.notes: The largest number of migrants to Germany historically have come from Turkey, especially during the guest worker programs in the 1960s and 1970s.
questions.learningTechniques: Associate the significant Turkish community in Germany with the country's history of labor migration.

resources.description: More about migration from Turkey to Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: In der DDR lebten vor allem Migrantinnen und Migranten aus …
questions.englishQuestion: In the GDR, most migrants came from …
questions.notes: In the GDR, labor migrants primarily came from socialist-friendly countries such as Vietnam, Poland, and Mozambique under bilateral agreements.
questions.learningTechniques: Remember that GDR migrant workers often came from socialist countries under government agreements.

resources.description: Overview of migration to the GDR.

questions.germanQuestion: Ausländische Arbeitnehmerinnen und Arbeitnehmer, die in den 50er und 60er Jahren von der Bundesrepublik Deutschland angeworben wurden, nannte man …
questions.englishQuestion: Foreign workers who were recruited by West Germany in the 1950s and 1960s were called …
questions.notes: The term 'Gastarbeiter' refers to the foreign workers who were invited to work in West Germany during the 1950s and 1960s, mainly from Southern Europe and Turkey.
questions.learningTechniques: Link the term 'Gastarbeiter' with the large wave of foreign labor migration during Germany's economic boom.

resources.description: Learn more about the history of guest workers in Germany.

questions.germanQuestion: Aus welchem Land kamen die ersten Gastarbeiterinnen und Gastarbeiter nach Bundesrepublik Deutschland?
questions.englishQuestion: From which country did the first guest workers come to West Germany?
questions.notes: The first guest workers to arrive in West Germany came from Italy, under a bilateral agreement signed in 1955.
questions.learningTechniques: Connect the start of guest worker recruitment with the Italian labor migration to Germany in the mid-20th century.

resources.description: More on the history of Italian guest workers in Germany.
